abstracts.cdata!:
The overall objective of the
            Privatization and Regulatory Capacity Building Technical
            Assistance Project is to increase the level of private
            sector investment in Gabon. The current program calls for:
            (a) facilitating rapid divestiture from state enterprises
            with major spin-off effects on factor costs and employment,
            in transport, power, telecommunications, and the largest
            agro-businesses; and (b) improving the efficiency of state
            spending in core areas directly aimed at poverty reduction.
            The project has five components: (1) Public understanding
            and support of the reform program -obtained by: (a) setting
            up and operating an information unit; (b) building
            government capacity to use the media effectively and
            establishing contacts with influential constituencies; (c)
            researching public opinion; and (d) training journalists on
            reporting economic and governance issues. (2) Regulatory
            framework and capacity building -financing (a) a regulatory
            agency for the infrastructure subsectors; (b) implementing
            regulations and laws to attract private investment; and (c)
            the training of regulatory agency staff. (3) Privatizing
            selected large public enterprises in priority sectors with
            financing for consultant and advisory services. (4)
            Increasing local participation in privatization -preparing
            to sell the government's minority shares by: (a)
            drafting regulations on financial markets, trading
            activities, and financial intermediaries; and (b) passing
            laws to establish and regulate mutual funds; and (c)
            updating current laws on securities issuance. (5) Improving
            the business environment and promoting investment -by
            financing (a) computerizing legal texts; (b) repealing,
            amending, updating, or enacting applicable business laws;
            (c) reviewing existing and alternative business dispute
            resolution mechanisms; (d) revising the Labor Code; and (e)
            auditing and financially restructuring the national social
            security agency.
